newsitem.title: GERMANY: German farm sector sees success in UN food summit.
newsitem.headline: German farm sector sees success in UN food summit.

text.p: German farm minister Jochen Borchert in a statement said the Rome U.N.-sponsored World Food Summit, which ended on Sunday, had set the right signals to provide better food security.
German farm union DBV, part of the German delegation, said separately the summit had demonstrated governments had a duty to ensure the right to food was extended across the globe.
Borchert said because the summit texts were adopted by 186 states, they carried the authority necessary for them to be put into action. Activists called them empty gestures.
"I expect (the texts) to bring about necessary changes in policy," Borchert said, adding Germany would continue to support self-help food production projects in many countries.
The declerations and plans of action pledge to halve the number of hungry people from the current 840 million by the year 2015.
DBV said the summit showed a total liberalisation of world farm trade -- called for by the U.S. and others -- was not the key to end poverty at the root of hunger.
DBV said it was more important for rich countries to support farmers efforts in the developing world directly than to aim for cut-throat price competition in world markets.
